Mrs. Maria Hilaria is a member of the group "La Esperanza," (Hope) and she lives in the region of San Martin in the province of Mariscal Caceres, in the district of Juanjui. She and her husband run a motor vehicle repair shop, they fix mostly cars but also work on public transportation vehicles. Their shop is located in their home. They complement this business with a side business of purchasing and selling cattle. With this loan, which they will repay in 6 months, they intend on purchasing spare car parts as well as more cattle to sell to customers who come from other regions and purchase the animals to be brought back and raised on the coast of the country. Maria Hilaria is 35 years old and lives with her husband and her three children. She is persisten and responsible, and wishes to see her children improve their lives. In the future, she hopes to open another side project where she will sell motor oil, lubricants, a project she had to put to the side for a while because she had to care for her newborn.

Translated from Spanish by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spare car parts and cattle.

loans.name: Maria Hilmer

texts.es:
La señora María Hilmer, socia del Grupo de Crédito Mientras Tanto “Mujeres Lideres”, vive en el departamento y provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la Venta de todo tipo de condimentos licuados y envasados como ajos, todo tipo de ajíes licuados. Vende en su puesto que tiene en el mercado No 02 de la ciudad, así mismo vende en su casa todo tipo de gaseosas, chupetes y hielos.
Con este préstamo de S/.700, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará cubitos y cajitas de caldos Magui en cajas, sillao, vinagre, cominos en kilos, orégano, ajinomoto, ajos en kilos para licuar y vender, diferentes tipos de ajíes para venderlos licuados y otros condimentos como palillo, pimentón entre otros, los cuales adquiere en gran cantidad para luego venderlos al menudeo.
María tiene 46 años de edad, vive con su esposo y con sus 02 hijos de sus hijos que aún dependen de ella, quienes además la apoyan en el negocio y en las actividades de la casa. Tiene como meta crecer en su negocio, surtir con otros productos de la misma variedad que los condimentos, porque sus productos tiene bastante demanda.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Hilmer is a member of the financial group "Mujeres Lideres," (Women Leaders) and she lives in the department and province of San Martin, in the district of Tarapoto. She sells all kinds of condiments, jarred items such as garlic and many types of liquid chili pepper sauces. She sells her wares from a stand in Market #2 in the city and she also sells her products from her home including different types of sodas, sweets and ice creams. With this loan, which she intends to repay in 6 months, she will purchase broth cubes and packages of Magui broth, soy sauce, vinegar, and in quantities of kilos, cumin, oregano, chili pepper, and garlic so that she can make them into liquids and then sell, she will also purchase different peppers to turn into liquid sauces and sell, other condiments such as hot yellow peppers, pimiento, among others she will purchase in large quantities to then sell on a smaller scale. Maria is 46 years old and she lives with her husband and her two sons who are still dependent on their parents, but who also help her with her business and household maintenance. She would like to see her business grow and to stock it with other products as well as a wider variety of items because her products are in high demand.

Translated from Spanish by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vinegar, cumin, oregano, garlic etc.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
La Señora Maria Isabel, socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Virtuosas”, vive en la Región y Provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la confección de lencería y todo tipo de prendas para damas, caballeros y niños, en su pequeño taller ubicado en su propia casa, en el Jr. Bolognesi  Nº 1095, Ella confecciona para luego salir a venderlos, así mismo trabaja en base a pedidos. Sus clientes son amigos, familiares y personas que llegan gracias a la recomendación de sus clientes ya existentes a quienes ella los trata muy bien para mantenerlos y asegurar sus ventas.

Con este préstamo de S/. 800, el cual será cancelado en 06 meses, comprará hilos de diferentes colores, telas de diversos colores y variedades para la confección de todo tipo de prendas, elásticos, blondas, cierres y todo lo que se requiere en la realización de sus trabajos. Desea contar con un buen stock porque sabe que ya llegan las fiestas de fin de año y ahí es cuando le llegan muchos pedidos.

Maria Isabel tiene  40 años de edad, vive con 01 de sus 02 hijos quien aún depende de ella y es la razón para seguir trabajando con mucho entusiasmo porque quiere darle una buena educación. Es una mujer muy independiente, amigable y emprendedora. Su meta es poner una tienda de vestidos para novias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Isabel is a member of the financial group "Mujeres Virtuosas," (Virtuous Women) and she lives in the region and province of San Martin, in the district of Tarapoto. She makes lace and many kinds of clothing items for men, women and children in her small workshop located in her own home. She makes the clothing and then goes to the market to sell them, as well as making items on commission. Her clients are her friends, family and those who come to her based on recommendations. She treats her customers well because she wants to keep them and to assure her sales. This loan will be repaid in 6 months and with it, she will purchase many different colored threads, fabrics, elastics, and zippers, among other things she needs to assemble her clothing items. She would like to maintain a large stock because the end of year parties are coming up and she will receive many requests for new clothing items. Maria Isabel is 40 years old and she lives with one of her two children, who still depends on her, which is why she continues to work with as much enthusiasm as she does, because she wants to give him a good education. She is an independent, friendly and hard working woman. Her goal is to open a store with bridal gowns.

Translated from Spanish by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase threads, fabrics, elastics and zippers, etc

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
La Señora Maria Luisa, socia del Banco Comunal “La Esperanza”, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, miel de abeja y hierbas medicinales. Su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa, en Prolongación La Merced S/N y sus clientes son mayormente los vecinos de su  barrio y personas que requieran de sus productos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes marcas y tamaños, entre otros, para poder surtir bien su negocio y sus clientes encuentren  lo que buscan, así como también tramitará sus documentos para formalizar su negocio. 

Maria Luisa tiene 38 años, vive con su esposo y con sus 02 hijos, los cuales son estudiantes y aún dependen de ella. Es una mujer trabajadora, que quiere seguir creciendo en su negocio y su meta es ampliar y dar seguridad a su local para surtir más el negocio y poder satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Luisa is a member of the financial group "La Esperanza" (Hope) and she lives in the region of San Martin in the province of Mariscal Caceres in the district of Juanjui. She sells groceries, honey and medicinal herbs. Her business is located in her home and her customers are mostly her neighbors and others who are in need of her products. This loan will be repaid in 6 months and will be used to purchase items such as rice, sugar, milk, cooking oil, canned items, toilet paper, detergents, soaps of different sizes and brands, among other things so that she can stock her business better and so that her customers can find what they are looking for, she will also be able to send off the documents that will formalize her business. Maria Luisa is 38 years old and she lives with her husband and her two children who are both students and are still dependent on her. She is a hard working woman who would like to see her business continue to grow. Her goal is to expand and secure her store and to better stock it so that she can meet her customers' demands.

Translated from Spanish by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as rice, sugar, milk and cooking oil.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora María pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Margaritas” y vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia El Dorado, distrito de Agua Blanca. Se dedica a la venta de comida tipo menú. El negocio está ubicado en su casa, la cual está en el Jr. Francisco Bolognesi S/N, lugar donde acuden diariamente sus comensales, los cuales son moradores de su comunidad y en su mayoría visitantes de otros lugares, que llegan a su distrito por distintas razones. 

Con este crédito de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar en saco, aceite en galón, gaseosas de diferentes marcas tamaños y sabores, y otros ingredientes que necesita para la preparación diaria de los platos que oferta a sus clientes como verduras, carnes (de res, cerdo, pollo, pescado), quiere tener todo listo para esperar las fiestas patronales de su distrito donde está asegurada sus ventas.

La señora María tiene 35 años de edad, es viuda y vive con sus 04 hijos que aún dependen de ella. Es una mujer decidida, alegre y buena administradora. Tiene como meta arreglar su local e implementar mejor su mobiliario porque su clientela va en aumento y quiere  atenderlos con mayor comodidad.
texts.en:
María belongs to the Las Margaritas community bank and lives in the San Martín region of El Dorado province, Agua Blanca district. She engages in the sale of traditional meals. The business is located in her home, which is in the neighborhood of Francisco Bolognesi. It is a place where diners gather on a daily basis, including both residents of the community and the majority who are visitors from other places—those who have come to her area for a variety of reasons. With this loan of $500 (1500 nuevos soles), which will be repaid in six months’ time, María will buy rice, sugar by the bag, oil by the gallon, various brands of carbonated beverages in a variety of sizes and flavors, and other ingredients necessary for the daily preparation of the dishes she offers to her customers, such as vegetables and meat (beef, pork, chicken and fish). She wants to have everything ready in anticipation of her district’s festivals in honor of patron saints when sales are assured. María is 35 years old, and a widow who lives with her four children who are still in the home. She is a determined woman, cheerful and a good manager. Her goal is to fix up her place and improve the furnishings because her clientele is growing and she wants to make them comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, oil, soft drinks, et cetera

location.town: Agua Blanca - El Dorado - San Martín

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: Pedro M. S. quiere hacer un cambio dentro de su casa el desea una barra en medio para dividir sala y comedor. Esto lo quiere hacer es para que se vea bonita su casa y diferente a las demás, también para que sus hijos pequeños tengan el menor riesgo de cualquier tipo de accidente. Para hacer la división de sala y comedor el necesita $150 dólares. Él es el sostén de la casa  su esposa se dedica al hogar y al cuidado de sus 2 hijos pequeños.
texts.en:
Pedro M. S. wants to remodel his home by placing a dividing wall between the living and dining rooms. He wants to beautify his home, making it different from those belonging to others and to prevent small children from being injured. It will take $150 to divide the living and dining rooms. Pedro is the breadwinner in house; his wife spends her time caring for the home and their two small children.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home remodeling

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es: Don Miguel tiene 53 años de edad, es casado y habita en el barrio Anexo Villa Libertad,  su esposa es ama de casa y ambos tienen dos hijos de 14 y 17 años de edad, los cuales están estudiando la secundaria. El negocio que tiene don Miguel es una zapatería, en el cual hace y repara zapatos, pues esta ha sido su fuente de trabajo ya que desde muy joven su papá le enseñó el oficio y le herederó la zapatería,  son cuarenta y cinco años de experiencias y es un negocio estable. Con la solicitud de préstamo lo quiere para invertir en materia prima en la compra de cuero, suelas, pega y todo lo que ocupa en su negocio. A largo plazo es seguir manteniendo su negocio, hacer mejoras en su local así como comprar otras maquinas para seguir haciendo ofreciendo un servicio excelente a sus clientes, poder seguir dando estudio a sus hijos para que sean hombres de buena educación.
texts.en:
Miguel is 53 years old, married, and lives in the neighborhood Anexo Villa Libertad. His wife is a housewife and his children are 14 and 17 years old, both of whom are high school students. Miguel’s business is a shoe store where he makes and repairs shoes. This business has been his source of work since he was very young when his father taught him this trade. He inherited the shoe store with 45 years of experience and stability. With this loan, he would like to invest in basic materials such as leather, soles, glue, and other items that are needed in his business. In the long term, he wants to continue maintaining his business, offering excellent service to his customers. Also, he wants to be able to continue sending his children to school so that they become men of great education.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Puchase basic materials for manufacturing shoes

loans.name: Karen

texts.es: Doña Karen habita en un barrio de la capital de Managua que se llama Francisco Morazán, tiene 34 años de edad, con dos hijos de 10 y 19 años de edad, que cursan sus estudios, es madre soltera. La Sra. Karen se ha preparado con sus estudios para salir adelante con su familia aunque se le ha hecho difícil ha logrado partes de sus objetivos y espera ayudar a sus hijos para que éstos también logren sus objetivos, estudió para Fisioterapeuta, y ahora desempeña su carrera en un centro de salud estatal, y tiene trece años de experiencia. Con la solicitud del préstamo que está haciendo es para infraestructura en la construcción de un porche de la casa, para lo cual necesita comprar materiales de construcción como piedra, arena, cemento y hierro. A largo plazo es poder seguir estudiando y así optar a otro cargo mejor y con mejores ingresos ayudar a sus hijos con los estudios para que sean personas con buen futuro.
texts.en:
Karen lives in a neighborhood of Managua called Francisco Morazan. She is 34 years old and a single mother of 2 children, ages 10 and 19, who are students. Karen has prepared herself with education in order to move forward with her family although it has been difficult to achieve parts of her goals. She hopes to support her children in order for them to fully achieve their goals. She studied physical therapy and has worked in a state health center for the past 13 years. With the loan that she is requesting, she would like to build a porch for her home. She needs to purchase materials such as stone, sand, cement, and iron. In the long term, she would like to continue studying and apply for a better job with a higher income to support her children during their studies that will allow them to have a grand future.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a porch

loans.name: Silvia Maria

texts.es: Silvia tiene 38 años de edad, habita en un barrio de la capital de Managua que se llama Hialeah, es casada y con tres hermosos hijos de 4,9 y 12 años de edad quienes cursan la primaria, su esposo trabaja y aporta a los gastos del hogar. El negocio de doña Silvia es la venta de helados en su casa también lava y plancha a domicilio, ya tiene cuatro años de estar trabajando así y de esta manera aporta a los gastos de su hogar. La solicitud de este préstamo es para infraestructura en la reparación del techo de uno de los cuartos ya que está en mal estado, y con las lluvia se le hace muy difícil esta situación, también desea construir un muro en frente de la casa para poder tener un poco mas de seguridad para su familia. A largo plazo es poder tener una pulpería surtida donde pueda generar mas capital, para tener un negocio sólido en donde pueda cubrir sus necesidades económicas.
texts.en:
Silvia is 38 years old and she lives in a neighborhood in the capital, Managua, which is called Hialeah. She is married and has 3 gorgeous kids who are 4, 9 and 12; they are in primary school. Her husband works and takes care of the household costs. Silvia works selling ice creams from her house, and she also washes and irons clothes from home. She has been doing this for 4 years and in this way helps with the household costs. She would like this loan for infrastructure, to repair the roof in one of their rooms which is in a bad state, and the rain makes this situation very difficult. She also wants to build a wall in front of the house for a bit more security for the family. In the long term she would like to have a well stocked grocery store to generate more capital, so she can have a solid business which will cover her economic needs.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a wall and repair the roof/Construcción de muro y reparación de techo

loans.name: Scarleth Marisol

texts.es: Scarleth es una joven de 25 años de edad, vende productos de cosméticos, ropa y prendas de oro, desde hace un año, negocio en el cual le ha ido bien ya que ha captado muchos clientes, vende al contado y al crédito. Habita en un barrio de la capital que se llama Batahola Sur, con tres hermosos hijos de 1,2 y 11 años de edad, su esposo está desempleado ya que esta difícil encontrar trabajo pero día a día sale para ver si  logra ubicarse. Actualmente cuenta sólo con sus ingresos para salir adelante en esta mala situación que está pasando con su esposo. Con la solicitud de préstamo es para comprar productos de ropa, cosméticos, zapatos, y así aumentar el inventario que actualmente tiene y poder colocar más entre sus clientes
texts.en:
Scarleth is a young woman of 25 and she sells cosmetic products, clothes and gold jewelery. She has been doing this for one year and business has gone very well, she has many clients and she sells for cash and on credit. She lives in a neighborhood of the capital called Batahola Sur with her 3 lovely kids who are 1, 2 and 11. Her husband is unemployed as it is very hard to find a job although everyday he goes out to see if he can find one. Now they can only count on her earnings to move forward out of this bad situation with her husband. The loan is to buy clothes, cosmetics and shoes, and thereby increase the inventory that she has now and to be able to show more to her clients.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, perfumes and clothes/Compra de cosméticos, perfumes y ropa

loans.name: Enoe Mercedes

texts.es:
La Sra. Enoe habita en un barrio de la capital Managua que se llama Batahola Sur, tiene 24 años de edad, con una hermosa hija de dos años, su esposo es comerciante ambulante de ventas de Cd y Juegos Videos. Doña Enoe tiene un pequeño salón de belleza  y también ayuda a su esposo a vender cd en su negocio. Inició hace tres años  cortando cabello en su casa pues siempre le ha gustado la belleza y la moda y con el tiempo logró comprar las herramientas necesarias para poder instalarse en el salón en donde ha logrado captar muchos clientes y espera obtener mas  cada día, ya que con la solicitud que está haciendo es para infraestructura en la remodelación del salón para dar mejor servicio.
También desea comprar mas productos que se utilizan cada día. A largo plazo es poder estar más estables tener mayor fuente de inversión, gozar de salud para poder ayudar a su hija en los estudios.
texts.en:
Enoe lives in a neighborhood in the capital of Managua which is called Batahola Sur. She is 24 years old and has a lovely 2 year old daughter. Her husband sells CDs and video games. Enoe has a small beauty salon and she also helps her husband by selling CDs in her shop. She started cutting hair in her house 3 years ago and she has always liked beauty and fashion. With time she got all the necessary equipment for the salon, she has got many clients and hopes to have more each day. She would like a loan for infrastructure, to remodel the salon to give a better service.

She also wishes to buy more everyday products. Long term she would like to be more stable, have a better source of income and enjoy health to be able to help her daughter in her studies.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve the infrastructure in her beauty salon/Mejorar la infraestructura del salón de belleza

loans.name: Koy

texts.en: Koy V., 39, has a business taking care the public toilets and gets a commission from her work. She also sells some stuff, such as ice-cream and soft drinks, there to earn an approximately US $10 in revenue. Her husband is a guard who takes care of the public garden in front of the Royal Palace, Phnom Penh city. He makes US $2 each day as well. This couple has two children, all of whom are students. Koy V. would like to take out a loan of US $1000 to buy more stuff to sell in front of the toilets. In the future, if she has enough money, she wants to become a grocery dealer. (She is pictured on the left hand.)

loans.use: Purchasing more stuff for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Lach Yim's Fishing Business Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of fifteen members, is located in Kuy Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Lach Y. is the village bank president; she has been selected by the members. She has 2-hectar where she can cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Ke Khon, is a fisherman. In order to improve this business, his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets; she will use the rest of the loan to purchase a new boat to replace the old one. She hopes that she can increase her income and improve her living conditions with this new loan. Mrs. Lach Y. is 55 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom immigrated to Thailand to work and another of whom is a farmer. The youngest one is still attending the local school. Mrs. Hor I. does not come to take a loan but her husband is, so he is presented in the picture instead.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Thirteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchasing new fishnets and a new boat

loans.name: Maksuda

texts.en: U. Maksuda, a seller of children’s wear imported from China, lives in the Spiotamen region where she is married and has two children. U. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2008, her first loan having helped her to establish the business. The stable income generated by her clothing sales enabled her to repay the loan promptly, and she is now applying for a four-month loan from Kiva in order to import new clothing and expand her enterprise.  U. is confident that her good taste in clothing and wide selection of products will allow her business to continue to grow.

loans.use: To purchase new goods and expand the business

loans.name: Regina Namwanje's Group

texts.en:
Regina is the leader of a 5-member group. She is a 38-year-old widow with 3 children aged between 18 and 13. All three children go to school. She rents a three-room house where she is staying with four people. Regina doesn't take care of any additional family member. They do have electricity but no running water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Regina deals in second-hand clothes and goes around door-to-door looking for customers. On average she can sell to 10 people, and she buys the clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.

Regina has been in this business for five years and has managed to educate her two children up to tertiary institution. Her major challenges are the rainy season, seasonality, and feeding the family is at times difficult. Regina plans to use this loan partly for her business and another part to pay school fees for her children. She is aspiring to get a permanent shop for her business and also to educate her children up to university.

loans.use: To increase the inventory for her business

loans.name: Ipagala D Group

texts.en:
Zena has been selling charcoal in Dodoma for three years. She is seeking her first loan so that she can purchase a greater quantity of charcoal to sell for profit. She works 10 hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $35 each month. She is hoping that the growth of her business as a result of the loan will result in increased profits that allow her to buy more food for her family and continue to expand her business.

Zena is 33 years old and single with one 13-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Margeth, Beatris, Veronica, and Atupele.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Annette Nakiryowa's Group

texts.en:
Annette is the leader of a group of 4 members. She is 45 years old and divorced with 2 children, aged 17 and 15 years, who go to school. She owns and resides in a two-roomed house, where she is staying with three people and taking care of three orphans. She gets some financial assistance from her former husband to look after the children. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day.

Annette resides and works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She runs a hotel in Kibuye (one of the city suburbs) and incurs transport costs for transportation of food for her customers' convenience. Her major monthly expenses include rent for the business premises (at 50000 per month), water and electricity bills. Annette receives an average of 50 customers daily. She has been with MCDT for six years and is servicing her twelfth loan. Besides running a small eating joint, she also sells bananas from her veranda. She wants to use this loan to increase stock and expand her business.

loans.use: To increase stock in her business

loans.name: Mrs. Keo Koem Lin's Grocery Store Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of twenty-one members, is located in Prey Morn Village in Kampong Chhnang Province; Mrs. Keo K. L. is the village bank president. She also owns a small grocery store in the local market. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it; consequently, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods for her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Loem Tun, has a small store where he can repair cassette players for an income. Mrs. Keo K. L. is 36 years old and the mother of four children, all of whom are attending the local school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Sixteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchasing more groceries

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Phan Sopeap's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people in Andoung Svay Village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed a village bank loan group and they will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Phan S. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the members. She is a vegetable seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy different kinds of vegetables to re-sell to her customers. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this new loan. Mrs. Phan S. is a 27-year-old widow with two children; one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is two years old.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of vegetables to re-sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mrs. Thon Kon Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thon K. is the group leader of four in Mean Chey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a pig breeder and her husband, M. Sok Sokhom, is an electrician. Since her pig breeding business is going well, Mrs. Thon K. is requesting a loan to buy four more piglets for breeding. Mrs. Thon K. is 39 years old and the mother of two children, who are attending the local school.

All the members in this group have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy four more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Sao Yin Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao Y. is the group leader of four who all live in Sre Uk village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a farmer who now faces a small problem because her field now is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Sao Y. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to support her field to make a better crop. Her husband, Mr. Soem Ren, helps her in the plantation. Mrs. Sao Y. is 36 years old and the mother of four children who are all attending the local school. (Mrs. Sao Y. did not come to accept the loan but her husband did so he present in the picture).

All the members in this group have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to support her field to make a better crop.

loans.name: Mrs. Phon Loan Group

texts.en:
Five members from Chrolong village in Kampong Chhnang province make up this group L.. Mrs. Phon L. is group leader and she owns 2-hectares for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. Chhun Chheun, is a fisherman who can catch only a little fish because he does not have enough fishing tools. In order to improve his business, his wife decided to ask for a L. to buy more fishnets for her husband's business. Mrs. Phon L. is 38 years old and the mother of five children, four of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is three years old.

All the members in this group L. have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the L. until the very end of the L. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the L. term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for her husband's business.

loans.name: Chom

texts.en: Mr. Chom V. is a villager in Kosh Ras Leu Village in Kandal Province. He is a firewood seller and his wife, Mrs. Yun Ran, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her household. Mr. Chom V. is a breadwinner who has only one business activity which cannot support his family well. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat in order to start a fishing business. Mr. Chom V. is 19 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is one year old. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a boat in order to start a fishing business.

loans.name: Nop

texts.en:
Mrs. Nop N. is a villager in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pei Village in Kandal Province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her household. Her husband, Mr. Mork Bun, is a fisherman in the local lake in the village. In his business, he now faces a small problem because his boat is too old and he cannot go to catch fish. Thus, his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat, and she will use the rest of the money to buy fishnets for her husband's business.

Mrs. Nop N. is 47 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are employed in different business activities while two are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a new boat and fishnets for her husband's business.

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum S. is a farmer in Chroy Pisey Village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who owns 0.5 hectare to cultivate rice. She is a 53-year-old widow with a child who is employed in a garment factory. Although Mrs. Prum S. and her child have different businesses, they still do not have enough money to buy 12 stilts to build a house, so Mrs. Prum S. decided to ask for a loan to buy them for this purpose. She hopes to improve her living conditions with this new loan.

loans.use: To buy 12 stilts to build a house

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm C., 40, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been working selling many kinds of meatballs, boiled duck eggs, roasted chicken wings and more to earn a living and is able to make US$3 each day of profit. Her husband is a wedding chef and sometimes acts as a motor-taxi driver. On average, he makes US$8 per day. Morm C. would like to take out a loan of US$200 to purchase more meatballs for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more meatballs for sale.

loans.name: Mr. Tet Norn Group

texts.en:
Mr. Tet N. is the group leader of four who all live in Tropang Buon Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Ket Pai, are farmers and also rice sellers. Since the second business is going well, they want to expand it so Mr. Tet N. decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell. Mr. Tet N. is 51 years old and the father of three children, who are all attending the local school.

Mrs. Nay S. and Mrs. Nay C. did not come to collect the loan but their husbands did, so they are present in the picture instead their wives.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more rice to re-sell.

loans.name: Bu

texts.en:
Mrs. Bu K. is a villager in Trapaing Krasang Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Ert Bo, is a construction worker who can only make a small income to support his family. Although they have different business activities, they still cannot support their family well. Thus, Mrs. Bu K. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a cow for breeding.

Mrs. Bu K. is 38 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of three years old. Her husband is shown on her right in the photo.

loans.use: to add to her savings to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Ipagala D Group

texts.en:
Luckesia has been a tailor in Dodoma, Tanzania, for eleven years. As a result of nine-hour work days, she is currently able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $20. This is Luckesia's first loan and she is going to put it towards a new sewing machine so that she may increase her sales. With the anticipated increase in her profit, Luckesia hopes to pay her children's school fees and begin to keep some money for savings.

Luckesia is 42 years old, single and has two children. She also cares for one additional dependant. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mollen, Agness, Adelfina and Stela.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chem L. is a farmer in Prey Kduoch Village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Kan Kea, is a construction worker who can only make a small income to support his family. In the business, he now faces a problem because he does not have enough construction tools so his wife has decided to ask for a loan to buy those tools for her husband's work.

Mrs. Chem L. is 25 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of one year old. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy construction tools for her husband

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Yoeun L., 37, is married and has one child. She is a rice farmer growing rice and other crops on her rice paddy, which is about 100 meters from her house. She makes very little in revenue because what she grow is primarily just to feed her household, and she does not have much of her crop left for sale. Her husband, Phai Kang, is a construction foreman. The people in her community normally contact him directly whenever they need him to construct their houses or other buildings. In order to complete his construction projects on time, Kang has to hire three or four other construction workers to help him, and he has to pay them every week. Recently this couple has faced a financial problem and they do not have enough money to pay their workers. (In reality, he could receive his wage fee from the building owner whenever his building is completed). So in order to handle this problem, Mrs. Yoeun L. and her husband would like to take a loan from KIVA via CREDIT MFI to help them pay their workers and then use the remaining money to buy more seed to expand their crops.

loans.use: To buy more seed for her crops

loans.name: Aom

texts.en:
Mrs. Aom S. is a villager in Prey Kduoch Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who earns very little. Her husband, Mr. Ol Ann, uses a motorbike pulling a cart to transport passengers as a source of income. His motorbike is very old so he spends a lot of money on gas and repairs.

In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Aom S. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a new motorbike for her husband's business. Mrs. Aom S. is 36 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom helps their father while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is also shown in the photo.

loans.use: to add to her savings to buy a new motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Ipagala D Group

texts.en:
Phoibe has been selling food in Dodoma, Tanzania for four years. She has a small stand in which she sells snacks that she cooks, vegetables, and small fish. She is taking out her first loan so that she can purchase more ingredients and items to sell. She currently works for seven hours every day and earns approximately $135 each month, but she is hoping that she can increase that profit so that she is better equipped to expand her business and begin to save some money for the future.

Phoibe is 29 years old, married, and has two children, ages 6 and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Baselisa, Emmy, Pasquna, and Christina.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her business

loans.name: Mim

texts.en: Mrs. Mim M. was born in 1963 and she now lives in Chan Teab Village in Takeo Province. She is a grocer and her husband, Mr. Nop Klot, is a farmer. Although they have different businesses, they cannot support their family well. Thus, Mrs. Mim M. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after her cow has been sold. Mrs. Mim M. has three children who are all enrolled in the local school. Her husband is present in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros S. N., 26, works selling women's clothes at a busy market and typically makes around $2.50 profit. She currently lives with her four-year-old child and her father in Bateay district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her husband has not lived with her since he became employed by a garment factory in Phnom Penh City, but he still comes to visit her two or three times per month. Ros S. N. has applied for a loan to buy clothes wholesale from a market in order to expand her inventory because her client base is growing and they have demanded fashionable clothes.

loans.use: To by clothes wholesale and resell them to meet growing customer demand

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. Lay S., 53, and her husband, Mr. Kong Bou, 51, live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have seven children: six sons and one daughter. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Two other children have full time employment. Two sons study in local schools.

Mrs. Lay has been selling fish since 1992. She buys them from a fishing lot a bit far from her home to sell at the Phnom Penh market and in her village market. Her husband is a chef and assists Lay in the fish selling business.

Lay is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en: Mr. Sophal P., 40, is a primary school teacher. He always leaves home to teach class at the primary school while his wife, Mrs. Yorn Shay, 37, works as a farmer. She has been farming since 1989. Sophal and his wife live with five children in the family home, all of whom are students. The children spend their free time helping their parents with the family business. This is the traditional farm season in which Cambodia's citizens grow rice. However, Sophal lacks the capital for operating the farm. Sophal requests a loan of 600,000 Riel (US$150) to purchase fertilizer for his wife to use growing the rice crop. The loan will help to increase rice yield higher than in previous years. The family lives in Ptasrong Commune, Pursat Province. (Mr. Sophal's wife is pictured because Sophal was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for the rice crop

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Chey R. P., 38, is a widow and lives in Phnom Penh with her child and her elderly mother. She has a business renting out rooms from her house and selling fried bananas to earn a living and is able to make US$ 8 each day. Mrs. Chey would like to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to build more rooms to rent out.

loans.use: To build more rooms to rent out

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina was born in 1959 and lives in Brijesnica Mala, the small agricultural village in Bosnia that she moved to during the Bosnian War after her village was evacuated. She is married and lives with her son, daughter, and ailing mother-in-law. Her husband and son were unable to find work either during or after the war, but her family survived by living off the land. Now they continue to raise cows and chickens and grow vegetables including tomatoes, cabbage and corn.

With the money earned from selling food to local markets, Mina was able to put her daughter through law school. Her son teaches a technology course at a local high school.

Mina now hopes to start growing and selling corn. She is requesting a loan of $425 to help her prepare, store and transport corn to local markets.

loans.use: To collect, store and transport corn.

loans.name: Ipagala D Group

texts.en:
Halima has been keeping livestock in Dodoma, Tanzania, for 12 years. She works for 9 hours every day and is able to earn approximately $100 each month. This is Halima's first access to a loan and she is looking forward to purchasing medicine, food and shelter for her livestock once she receives it. She hopes that by improving the conditions for her chickens, she will be able to increase her profits. She intends to use the profit to buy more food for her family and to continue to expand her business.

Halima is 48 years old and widowed. She has four children between the ages of 21 and 30 and she also cares for three additional dependants. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Jane, Grace, Magreth and Furugelia.

loans.use: To buy medicine, food and shelter for her livestock.

loans.name: Thoar

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoar N. is a farmer in Sla Village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Soy Touch, helps out with their farm. Aside from this business, he is a motorbike taxi driver who can only make a small income to support his family. They have two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the younger one is attending the local school.

Although these family members have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well so Mrs. Thoar N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after her cow has been sold. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothea L., 33, and her husband were married in 1997. They have two children: one son and one daughter. All of their children study in the local school. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sothea has been a silk weaver for fifteen years, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a wooden house builder.

Sothea is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch P., 28, is married and lives with her young child and her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a garment factory worker, typically making $3.00 per day. Her husband has a business planting many kinds of vegetables on the farm near their house. He started growing vegetables in 2000 and is able to make $10.00 in revenue each day. Mrs. Touch would like to ask for a loan of $1000.00 to purchase good seeds for her husband.

Mrs. Touch P.'s husband is pictured here above in his field, because Touch P. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview.

loans.use: To purchase seeds

loans.name: Mersiha

texts.en:
Mersiha, 36 and living in Đurđevik, a small agricultural village in Bosnia, is married and has two daughters in primary school. Because her husband is retired with a disability, she single-handedly supports her family by knitting high-quality traditional tablecloths and decorative wall hangings, receiving orders from both Bosnia and Germany.

Because Mersiha lives in a very rural location, there is a $700 deposit required to set up an electrical connection at her house. She is requesting a loan of $350 to help her meet this deposit requirement.

loans.use: To cover the costs of getting electricity to her home.

loans.name: Sok-Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok-aun Y., 34, is widow with one daughter. She lives with her parents and one brother and one sister in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sok-aun started weaving silk three years ago, a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Klout

texts.en: Klout S., 41, is married and lives with one child and her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is one of the vendors who works selling groceries in the village, making around US$7 in revenue. Her husband, Moeun Thol, 55, works in construction and normally makes US$5 per day. Klout would like to ask for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more groceries for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for sale.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim R. works as a farmer growing rice and vegetables. She has to get up early in the morning to pick her output from her paddy then sell it to the people in a market. With her business activity she can typically make around $2.00 a day. Her husband works breeding ducks, cooking and selling them to the people in his area and making about $4.00 each day in revenue. She and her husband would like to take a loan from CREDIT to reinvest in their businesses by purchasing more seed and ducks. (Her husband is pictured while Mrs. Sim R. is not available).

loans.use: To buy seed and ducks

loans.name: Merima

texts.en: Merima, 23 and married with a two-year-old son, lives in Đurđevik, an agricultural village in Bosnia.  Merima owns a small stand at the local marketplace where she sells clothing and accessories.  Recently, she has started to supplement her income by using a computer to prepare diplomas and announcements for local schools and businesses.  Eager to develop this business so as to be less reliant upon her clothing stand for income,  Merima is requesting a loan to purchase a computer that will allow her to offer higher quality services and products to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase a new computer.

loans.name: Vanthol

texts.en:
Mr. Vanthol P., 30, and his wife, Mrs. Loeng Phun, 30, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2001 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children study in local schools.

Mr. Vanthol has been fishing for fifteen years. He does fishing from the lake in the village and his wife sells his catch in a market near his village and the Mekong River. He is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase a motor for his boat and fishing nets.

loans.use: To purchase a motor and fishing nets

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy Y. is a farmer who lives with one of her three children. Living in the Kampong Cham province, she typically makes $1.00 per day and is aided by one of her children who works growing crops. Her husband owns a big grinding mill and provides service to the people in the area to earn about $3.30 per day. The Kampong Cham area has not seen favorable weather conditions for farming this past year. Along with increased inflation, it has been a difficult year economically in much of Cambodia. As a farmer, Tuy Y. is taking a lot of the brunt of the economic downturn. That is why she has approached CREDIT with a request for a loan. Tuy Y. is asking for a loan of $400.00 to purchase a cow to pull the grinding mill, a purchase that she sees as a good opportunity to increase her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Miradeta

texts.en: Miradeta was born in 1960 and lives in Šićki.  She has a husband and two sons, one of whom attends high school while the other is an adult who works outside her home. Miradeta, a housewife who has started growing vegetables in a small greenhouse in order to supplement her husband’s income, is requesting a loan through Women for Women International to buy seeds and minerals for her greenhouse.  She will plant the vegetables in the autumn, and hopes to have a small harvest by early spring.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and minerals to grow vegetables.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha N., 50, and her husband, Mr. Chhon Yan, 49, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1988 and have two daughters. Their oldest daughter is married and lives outside the family home while the youngest daughter is a garment factory worker.

Sokha has been a silk weaver since she was young, a skill she acquired from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Chhon, a fisherman since 1988, sells his catch to the villagers.

Sokha is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase silk materials for her weaving and bamboo, nets, and other materials for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo, nets, and other materials for fishing and  silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Mkombozi A Group

texts.en:
Noadia, 31 years old and divorced with three children aged 2, 9, and 12, as well as three additional dependents, has been selling drinks in Dodoma, Tanzania since 2006. She works 12 hours everyday and nets a profit of approximately $65 each month.

Noadia is requesting her first loan in order to expand this young business and buy a greater quantity of water, soda, and beer to sell at her shop. As her sales increase and her profit grows, she hopes to put more money towards food for her family.

Noadia will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Rose and Amina.

loans.use: To buy more water, soda, and beer to sell.

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Mr. Socheat H., 30, and his wife, Mrs. Kimhoin Houn, 30, live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2002 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Their daughter studies in a local school.

Mr. Socheat has been farming since he was young. He grows many types of vegetables and rice in his farmland. His wife assists him in their farming business. He is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase a water pump, seed, fertilizer, and pesticide for farming.

loans.use: To purchase a pump, seed, fertilizer, and pesticide for farming.

loans.name: Mirzeta

texts.en:
Mirzeta, who is married and works with her husband at home on several businesses including wood-cutting and raising poultry, was born in 1955 and lives in Đurđevik. She now hopes to develop a bee-keeping business, as her home is located in a good location for raising bees, and she expects that she will be able to produce high-quality honey.

Mirzeta is requesting a loan of $425 through Women for Women International to prepare the conditions for her bees to survive the winter. This includes purchasing medicine and food for the bees.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and food for bees.

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mrs. Mai K. H., 41, is the mother of three children, aged sixteen, fourteen and eleven. She has just started her business selling Khmer cake (banana fried with flour, which has a unique flavor). With her business activity, she can typically make about $3 each day in revenue.

To generate more income for the household, her husband is self-employed as a construction foreman and makes about $10 per day.

Mai K. H. has applied for this loan to purchase more construction tools for her husband, as right now there is shortage of construction tools.

loans.use: To buy more construction tools for her husband

loans.name: Cheam

texts.en: Cheam M., 30, is married and lives with three children and her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2003, she has been working selling bananas to earn a living and is able to make about US$ 1.30 per day. Her husband is a farmer growing corn. On average, he makes US$ 2 per day. Cheam M. would like to take out a loan of US$ 500 to hire workers to plow their farmland and harvest their crops.

loans.use: To hire workers to plow their farmland and harvest their crops.

loans.name: Chailim

texts.en:
Mrs. Chailim S., 36, and her husband, Mr. Srun Chum, 36, live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married for eleven years and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children study in a local school.

Chailim has been a silk weaver for six years and has been a rice farmer since she was young. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Srun is a wooden houS. builder and rice farmer as well.

Chailim is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchaS. silk materials for her weaving and a water pump for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and a water pump

loans.name: Mkombozi A Group

texts.en:
Mary has been selling soaps and clothing at her shop in Dodoma, Tanzania for five years. She works 12 hours every day and earns a monthly profit of approximately $85. She is hoping that by taking out her first loan, she will be able to purchase more inventory for her shop and increase her sales. If she succeeds in earning more profit, she will use the additional funds towards growing her business further.

Mary is 35 years old, married, and has three children, ages 5, 9, and 12. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Paulina, Nyangeta, and Magreth.

loans.use: To buy more soaps and clothes for her shop.

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en: Khadija is a 29-year-old mother of five children, whose ages range from six months to 13 years old.  She started her small grocery store in 2000.  It is open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.  This is her first loan from BRAC Tanzania.

loans.use: To buy more stock and expand her business

loans.name: Slađana

texts.en:
Slađana is 38 and lives in Bijeljina, a rapidly-expanding town in northeast Bosnia. She is not married. She works in a hair salon, where she sells cosmetics and offers make-overs to clients.

Slađana requests a 600 KM loan from Women for Women International so that she can buy additional cosmetics to attract more customers. This is her first loan request.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to attract new customers.

loans.name: Hut

texts.en:
Hut Y., 48, grows rice to earn a living and is able to make less than US$1 each day. She says growing rice is hard and uses a lot of labor. The weather conditions have not been favorable for farming this past year. Along with increased inflation, it has been a difficult year economically in much of Cambodia. She plants rice two times a year; first, in the rainy season which takes about 6-7 months, and second, in the dry season but there are only 3-4 months to collect the harvest. 

Her husband, Ton Hun, 48, has a business selling ice-cream and makes US$4 per day. Besides farming and selling ice-cream, this couple is also raising pigs from their home for extra income. Hut Y. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to breed more pigs and to purchase feed as well.

loans.use: To breed more pigs and purchase feed.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn P., 29, and her husband, Mr. Thach Him, 37, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2004 and have two sons, one of whom studies in the local school.

Sarorn has been a silk weaver for fifteen years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Thach is a horse car driver and a fisherman. He carries people, goods, and firewood from his village to other places.   

Sarorn is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Zorica

texts.en:
Zorica was born in 1977 and lives in Bijeljina, a rapidly-expanding town in northeast Bosnia. She is married and has one child with a husband works in a telecommunications company. She owns and works in a hair salon. Zorica requests a 600KM loan from Women for Women International to invest in her salon business. She will use the loan to purchase supplies for her salon so that she can offer more services to her clients.

This is her first microfinance loan.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for a salon.

loans.name: Soem

texts.en: Soem S. is married and has a pool table to provide service to the local people. She earns less than one dollar per day, while her husband has a business catching fish. This couple has one little child. Soem would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase fishing tools for her husband and to purchase another pool table. She said her husband started fishing in 2005 and she just purchased her pool table in 2006.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools and a pool table

loans.name: Thlang

texts.en:
Mrs. Thlang C. is married with five children and works as a housewife. Her husband, Uy So C., is the head of the family and works as a construction foremen, making about $3.00 each day for his household. One of her children works at a factory and can earn around $1.50 per day for his household. 

Given the amount of money her child makes at work and the money he spends on a motor taxi commuting to work, it is not profitable for him to work. Thus Mrs Thlang C. would like to request a loan from KIVA to purchase a motor-bike for him to reduce his expenses. She believes this will increase her family’s savings.

loans.use: To buy a motor bike to reduce the family's transportation expenses

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mr. Sina N. is 26 years old. He is a Khmer Farmer who has been farming since 1999. His wife, Mrs. Sokhoeun Yon, is 23. She is also a farmer and spends a lot of time caring for their two young children. They both earn approximately $3.00 each day. 

Sina lacks working capital, so he decided to seek a loan of 500,000 Riel (US$125.00) to buy rice seeds to grow a rice crop. Sina hopes the loan will improve his business and his ability to support his family with a comfortable life and adequate daily expenses. They all live in Ptasrong Commune, Pursat Province. (Mr. Sina's wife is pictured because Sina was not available.)

loans.use: To buy rice seeds to grow a rice crop

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon S., 37, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur, who works selling groceries and lottery tickets. On average, she makes about US$2.30 per day, while her husband works in construction and makes US$3.30 per day. Two of her children are employed in different work; selling traditional medicine and acting as a worker. The last one is a student.

Mrs. Phon would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to make three investments: first, to purchase more traditional medicine for her children; second, to add to her grocery inventory; and third, to rent farm land to grow corn.

loans.use: To buy groceries and traditional medicine, and to rent farm land to grow corn.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap S., 44, and her husband, Mr. Sambath Kong, 48, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. Two of their sons are construction workers. One of their other sons is helping his mother spin thread, and the youngest studies in the local school. The two daughters are silk weavers; one of them is married and lives in the family home.

Sopheap has been a silk weaver for twenty-eight years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Sambath is a wooden house builder and a rice farmer.   

Sopheap is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase silk materials for her and her daughters' weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sin S. is 23 years old and lives with her 26-year-old husband in Kampong Cham.  She is currently pregnant, but continues to work as a grocer and earns about $1 each day, while her husband works as a blacksmith and earns about $5 each day.  In order to help her husband expand his business and thereby more effectively support their family when her baby is born, Sin is requesting a loan of $1,000, which will be used to purchase more sophisticated blacksmith tools.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith tools.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en: Ashura is a 33 year old mother of three children, ages 3, 5 and 7.  She started a small clothing store at the beginning of 2008.  It is open from 7 am to 9 pm and she has been earning $100 per month.

loans.use: To buy a wider range of clothing to improve her business

loans.name: Tha

texts.en: Tha S. is 29 years old and lives with her 28-year-old husband in a small village outside of Phnom Penh and across the Mekong River.  She married her husband in 2000, and together they have raised one daughter who is currently in school.  Tha has worked as a silk weaver since 2001, after learning the trade from her sister-in-law, and her husband builds wooden houses and caters for weddings and other ceremonies in their village.  Tha sells the silk she weaves to a merchant, who then distributes the cloth in Phnom Penh.  In order to expand her business and purchase a motorcycle for her husband's construction business, Tha is requesting a loan of $500.

loans.use: To purchase more silk weaving and to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Mkombozi A Group

texts.en:
Anna is 50 years old, married, and has 9 children between the ages of 15 and 33. In addition, she cares for three dependents. Anna has been selling food and charcoal in Dodoma, Tanzania, for 10 years, and while she is currently earning a profit of approximately $15 each month, she is hoping that by taking out her first loan she will be able to increase her profit. She intends to put any additional money she earns as a result of the loan towards buying more food for her family.

Anna will be sharing this loan with her sub-group members, Ester, M., Jesca, Claudia, and Martha.

loans.use: To buy more beans, maize, and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Ul

texts.en: Ul C. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and their six children in Kampong Cham.  As a rice farmer, Ul earns less than $1 each day and often has to work extra hard with three of her children to make up for poor weather conditions and the lack of rain.  Inflation has also made it difficult for rice farmers in her area to turn a profit, because the price of fertilizer and rice seeds has increased drastically.  Although her husband works hard as a local teacher and manages a battery recharging business, the price of gas has also hurt his profits and he now earns only $5 each day.  In order to consolodate and improve her husband's battery recharging business, Ul is requesting a loan of $1200, which will be used to replace the motor on their battery recharger.Ul C. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband is pictured here above.

loans.use: To replace the motor on a batter recharger.

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinat T., 29, and her husband, Mr. Visot Phalchan, 24, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in early 2008.

Sinat has been selling grocery items for two years and has been a tailor for two years as well. She buys grocery items from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale at her home. Her husband is assisting her in the business.

Sinat is requesting a loan of US$ 300 T. purchase more grocery items for re-sale and for her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for re-sale

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and their five children in Kampong Cham.  Three of their children are students and one is currently employed as a garment worker.  Although Sok works hard as a rice farmer, poor weather conditions, a lack of rain, and skyrocketing fertilizer and seed prices have all reduced her profit to the point that she earns only $1 each day.  Her husband also works hard collecting palm juice and refining it to sugar, allowing him to earn about $2 each day.  In order to move away from the unprofitable business of rice farming, Sok is requesting a loan of $500, which will be used to purchase a cow that her family will raise and eventually sell.

loans.use: To purchase one cow for sale.
